exercises.exercise:
Look at the libraries for one of your favourite programming languages and try to find implemenations of List, USet, and SSet interfaces. The exact names maybe different, but most languages and libraries implement these interfaces.

Here are some of the languages we know about:

C++
In the C++ Standard Template Library, there are several implementations of the List interface, including vector, list, and slist. The USet interface is implemented by the hash_set class and the SSet interface is implemented by the hash_set class.

The STL also includes the map and hash_map implementations of the Map interface as well as restricted lists, including the queue, stack, and deque.

Python
In the standard Python libraries, the List interface is implemented by the list class, the USet interface is implemented by the set class, and the Map interface is implemented by the dict class. The standard Python library does not include any implementation of the SSet interface, though the third-party sortedcontainers library provides a SortedSet class.
Java
In Java, the List interface is implemented by the Vector, ArrayList, and LinkedList classes, among others. The Uset interface is called the Set interface and is implemented by the HashSet class. The SSet interface is called the SortedSet interface and is implemented by the TreeSet class.

Java also has the Map interface that is implemented by the HashMap and SortedMap classes. The Java SDK also contains the Stack and ArrayDeque classes that implement the Stack and Deque interfaces.

How about other languages like PHP, JavaScript, Perl, Ruby, Objective-C, C#, Swift, or Perl?

Do as many as you can of Exercises 1.1–1.7 in the textbook. Use any programming language you like. (Note: For most of these exercises it helps if you've done the previous exercise for hte programming language you've chosen.)
